Description: Eleven rosettes of green glazed composition: with a suspension loop on the back, intended for stitching onto a cloth headband. Each is perforated with small slits. In the centre is the boss coloured black.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Matmar, Grave 31/509 Found at the neck of a child
Curator's comments: The rosettes were found at the neck of a child but almost certainly came originally from a head-band. Fifteen rosettes were discovered, but four have remained in Cairo (JE 55922-5). Of the parallels quoted by Brunton, in G. Brunton, ‘Matmar’ (London, 1948), 47, the rosette from Haraga is now at Oxford, Ashmolean Museum 1914.657. Also from this burial: bracelet or necklace with amulet (1932,1213.24), bracelet or necklace (1932,1213.25), necklace (1932,1213.23). Bibliography: G. Brunton, ‘Matmar’ (London, 1948),35, 47;'pl.XXXII, 79; Tomb register, pl.XXVI; Bead register, pl.LXXII; 'British Museum Quarterly' 6 (1931), 29; The British Museum, 'Jewellery through 7000 years' [exhibition catalogue] (London, 1976), no. 17.
Bibliographic references: Andrews 1981 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities. Jewellery I (326)
